didnp 0.1.0
  • Reference

    Treatment Effect Estimators

    didnpreg.Rd

    The didnpreg command contains tools for computing both heterogenous and average treatment effects for the treated in a model-free differences-in-differences framework.

    Usage

    didnpreg(...)

# S3 method for formula
didnpreg(
  formula,
  data = stop("argument 'data' is missing"),
  subset,
  bwmethod = "opt",
  boot.num = 399,
  TTx = FALSE,
  TTb = TRUE,
  print.level = 1,
  cores = 4,
  seed = 17345168,
  ...
)

# S3 method for default
didnpreg(
  outcome,
  regressors,
  id,
  time,
  treatment,
  treatment_period,
  weights = NULL,
  bwmethod = "opt",
  boot.num = 399,
  TTx = FALSE,
  TTb = TRUE,
  print.level = 1,
  cores = 4,
  seed = 17345168,
  ...
)

    Arguments

    formula

    an object of class formula (or one that can be coerced to that class): a symbolic description of the model. The details of model specification are given under `Details'

    data,

    # name of the data frame; must be specified if the 'formula' method is used

    subset

    NULL, optional subsample of 'data'

    bwmethod

    "opt", # plug-in is rule of thumb for continuous and basic for categorical, can be cross-validation

    boot.num

    399,

    TTx

    FALSE

    TTb

    FALSE

    print.level

    the level of printing; larger number implies more output is printed. Default is 1. 0 suppresses all printing.

    cores

    Integer specifies the number of cores to be used for parallel computation.

    outcome

    a vector, matrix, or data frame of length \(NT\). The outcome can be continuous or dummy.

    regressors

    a data frame with \(NT\) rows that contains regressors. A data frame is required to identify the type/class of each regressor.

    id

    a vector, matrix, or data frame of length \(NT\) that identifies the unit of observation.

    time

    a vector, matrix, or data frame of length \(NT\) that specifies in which period id is observed.

    treatment

    a vector, matrix, or data frame of length \(NT\) with zeros for the control and ones for the treated observations.

    treatment_period

    a vector, matrix, or data frame of length \(NT\) with zeros for the period before treatment and ones for the period of treatment and after.

    weights

    NULL,

    Value

    didnpreg returns a list containing:

    esampleA vector of TRUE/FALSE values identifying observations used in estimation. Relevant for the 'formula' method but complete cases will also be checked in the matrix method
    esample_treatedA vector of TRUE/FALSE values identifying observations used in estimation and is treated (intersection of esample and treatment)
    esample_TTaA vector of TRUE/FALSE values identifying observations used in estimation of TTa)
    esample_TTbA vector of TRUE/FALSE values identifying observations used in estimation of TTb. Returned only if TTb = TRUE)
    Nnumber of units of obs, defined by the id
    N_dtthe number of observations used as training data for each conditional expectation
    T_inumber of observations in each id
    bwsbandwidth(s) for the data
    TTxthe DiD estimators of the conditional TT (also known as CATET) (equation 2.12)
    TTa
    TTbNULL is option TTaOnly is used

    Details

    All estimations are based. y ~ x1 + x2 | id | time | treatment | treatment_period | weights

    References

    ... (...). This. Journal of , 1(1), 1-1 https://doi.org/10.

    Author

    Oleg Badunenko oleg.badunenko@brunel.ac.uk, Daniel J. Henderson djhender@cba.ua.edu, Stefan Sperlich stefan.sperlich@unige.ch

    Examples

    if (FALSE) {
  didnpreg(jhklangkjhakgkjh)
}
